titles: PUSS IN BOOTS: THE LAST WISH
critics consensus: Arriving more than a decade after the previous installment, the smart, sweet, and funny Puss in Boots: The Last Wish proves some franchises only get better with age.
Producer: Mark Swift

critics consensus: While its social commentary relies on basic ingredients, The Menu serves up black comedy with plenty of flavor.
Producer: Adam McKay, Betsy Koch, Will Ferrell

critics consensus: Featuring some of Martin McDonagh's finest work and a pair of outstanding lead performances, The Banshees of Inisherin is a finely crafted feel-bad treat.
Producer: Graham Broadbent, Peter Czernin, Martin McDonagh

critics consensus: The Pale Blue Eye lacks its source material's piercing gaze, but this well-cast mystery is just intriguing enough to investigate.
Producer: Christian Bale, Scott Cooper, John Lesher, Tyler Thompson

critics consensus: Led by an outstanding Michelle Yeoh, Everything Everywhere All at Once lives up to its title with an expertly calibrated assault on the senses.
Producer: Joe Russo, Anthony Russo, Mike Larocca, Dan Kwan, Daniel Scheinert, Jonathan Wang

critics consensus: Part memoir, part ode to the power of the movies, The Fabelmans finds Steven Spielberg digging at the family roots that helped make him a beloved filmmaker -- and proves he hasn't lost his magic touch.
Producer: Kristie Macosko Krieger, Steven Spielberg, Tony Kushner

critics consensus: empty
Producer: Unavailable

titles: GLASS ONION: A KNIVES OUT MYSTERY
critics consensus: Glass Onion: A Knives Out Mystery brings back Benoit Blanc for another wildly entertaining mystery rounded out by an outstanding ensemble cast.
Producer: Rian Johnson, Ram Bergman

critics consensus: Smart, self-aware, and all too timely, this slasher co-written by Kevin Williamson is Sick in all the best ways.
Producer: Ben Fast, Kevin Williamson, Bill Block

critics consensus: An earthbound story with its eyes on the stars, Mars One finds universally resonant themes within one Brazilian family's specific struggles.
Producer: Thiago Macêdo Correia, André Novais Oliveira, Gabriel Martins, Maurilio Martins

titles: THERE'S SOMETHING WRONG WITH THE CHILDREN
critics consensus: empty
Producer: Paige Pemberton, Paul Uddo

critics consensus: Honoring real-life history while delivering impactful drama, Devotion is a straightforward biopic elevated by standout performances from a talented cast.
Producer: Thad Luckinbill, Trent Luckinbill, Molly Smith, Rachel Smith

critics consensus: Led by Frankie Corio's tremendous performance, Aftersun deftly ushers audiences to the intersection between our memories of loved ones and who they really are.
Producer: Mark Ceryak, Amy Jackson, Barry Jenkins, Adele Romanski

critics consensus: White Noise may occasionally struggle with its allegedly unfilmable source material, but Noah Baumbach succeeds in finding the humorous heart of its surprisingly timely story.
Producer: Noah Baumbach, David Heyman, Uri Singer

critics consensus: A taut thriller that contains a wealth of social commentary, Emily the Criminal is stolen by Aubrey Plaza's terrific work in the title role.
Producer: Tyler Davidson, Aubrey Plaza, Drew Sykes

critics consensus: empty
Producer: Les Weldon, Yariv Lerner, Jeffrey Greenstein, Jonathan Yunger, Hank Hoffman, Sam Schulte

critics consensus: Despite an intriguing array of talent on either side of the camera, Don't Worry Darling is a mostly muddled rehash of overly familiar themes.

critics consensus: empty
Producer: Nick Santora, Jeremy Kipp Walker

critics consensus: empty
Producer: Robert Dean, Corey Large

critics consensus: Bullet Train's colorful cast and high-speed action are almost enough to keep things going after the story runs out of track.
Producer: Kelly McCormick, David Leitch, Antoine Fuqua

critics consensus: Black Adam may end up pointing the way to an exciting future for DC films, but as a standalone experience, it's a wildly uneven letdown.
Producer: Beau Flynn, Hiram Garcia, Dwayne Johnson, Dany Garcia

critics consensus: Amsterdam has a bunch of big stars and a very busy plot, all of which amounts to painfully less than the sum of its dazzling parts.
Producer: Arnon Milchan, Matthew Budman, Anthony Katagas, David O. Russell, Christian Bale

critics consensus: Nicolas Cage's first Western may be a bit of a genre departure for the prolific actor, but in most respects, it's merely a return to his Old Way of picking up roles in disappointingly subpar projects.
Producer: Brett Donowho, Micah Haley, Robert Paschall Jr., R. Bryan Wright, Sasha Yelaun

critics consensus: A fresh spin on the classic slasher formula, X marks the spot where Ti West gets resoundingly back to his horror roots.
Producer: Jacob Jaffke, Kevin Turen, Harrison Kreiss

critics consensus: Smart, darkly humorous, and above all scary, Barbarian offers a chilling and consistently unpredictable thrill ride for horror fans.
Producer: Arnon Milchan, Roy Lee, Raphael Margules, J.D. Lifshitz

critics consensus: empty
Producer: Samantha Jennings

critics consensus: but when one of them is found dead, she is immediately cast by the community as the main suspect. As the case unfolds, the verdict as to what actually happened becomes increasingly unclear, threatening to reveal the many secrets that lay within the marsh. titles: ALL QUIET ON THE WESTERN FRONT
critics consensus: Both timely and timeless, All Quiet on the Western Front retains the power of its classic source material by focusing on the futility of war.

critics consensus: Top Gun: Maverick pulls off a feat even trickier than a 4G inverted dive, delivering a long-belated sequel that surpasses its predecessor in wildly entertaining style.

critics consensus: It might be more impressive on a technical level than as a piece of storytelling, but Avatar reaffirms James Cameron's singular gift for imaginative, absorbing filmmaking.

critics consensus: The standard rock biopic formula gets all shook up in Elvis, with Baz Luhrmann's dazzling energy and style perfectly complemented by Austin Butler's outstanding lead performance.
Producer: Gail Berman, Baz Luhrmann, Catherine Martin, Patrick McCormick, Schuyler Weiss, Andrew Mittman

critics consensus: Guillermo del Toro's Pinocchio delivers fully on its title -- which is to say it's a visually stunning adaptation that embraces its source material's darkness.

critics consensus: Writer-director-star B.J. Novak could have taken a sharper approach to this dark comedy's deeper themes, but if you're in the mood for a slyly smart mystery, Vengeance is yours.
Producer: Jason Blum, Adam Hendricks, Greg Gilreath

critics consensus: empty
Producer: Karla Badillo, Maria Jose Cordova, Rafael Ley, Gabriela Maldonado

critics consensus: All hail Viola Davis! The Woman King rules.
Producer: Cathy Schulman, Viola Davis, Julius Tennon, Maria Bello

critics consensus: The atmosphere's absorbing and the story is fascinating, but The Wonder of this period drama really lies in Florence Pugh's remarkable performance.
Producer: Tessa Ross, Juliette Howell, Ed Guiney, Andrew Lowe

critics consensus: Strange World is a Disney milestone in terms of representation -- but as a storytelling experience, this dazzlingly animated adventure offers little audiences haven't already seen.
Producer: Roy Conli

critics consensus: Admirable for its originality and ambition even when its reach exceeds its grasp, Nope adds Spielbergian spectacle to Jordan Peele's growing arsenal.

critics consensus: It isn't deep or groundbreaking, but what it lacks in profundity, Puss in Boots more than makes up for with an abundance of wit, visual sparkle, and effervescent charm.
Producer: Joe Aguilar, Latifa Ouaou

critics consensus: Hellbender stirs a boiling cauldron of adolescent angst, serving up a coming-of-age story with dark horror overtones.

Producer: Toby Poser

critics consensus: To Leslie's familiar framework is granted extra depth through a stellar Andrea Riseborough and a sensitive and nuanced approach to the cycle of addiction.
Producer: Eduardo Cisneros, Ceci Cleary, Claude Dal Farra, Brian Keady, Kelsey Law, Jason Shuman, Philip Waley

critics consensus: empty
Producer: Alexander Nevsky, Ruslan Vitryanyuk

critics consensus: The Innocents chillingly subverts the purity of youth in a powerfully acted thriller that lingers long after the credits roll.

critics consensus: Deeply creepy visuals and a standout Sosie Bacon further elevate Smile's unsettling exploration of trauma, adding up to the rare feature that satisfyingly expands on a short.

critics consensus: Knives Out sharpens old murder-mystery tropes with a keenly assembled suspense outing that makes brilliant use of writer-director Rian Johnson's stellar ensemble.

critics consensus: Jurassic World Dominion might be a bit of an improvement over its immediate predecessors in some respects, but this franchise has lumbered a long way down from its classic start.

critics consensus: A bloody revenge epic and breathtaking visual marvel, The Northman finds filmmaker Robert Eggers expanding his scope without sacrificing any of his signature style.
Producer: Robert Eggers, Mark Huffam, Lars Knudsen, Arnon Milchan, Alexander Skarsgård

critics consensus: empty
Producer: Romuald Boulanger, Marc Frydman, Robert Ogden Barnum

critics consensus: A funny, emotional glimpse at the dynamic between a psychiatrist and his patient, Stutz heartwarmingly underscores the importance of an active focus on one's mental health.

critics consensus: Hereditary uses its classic setup as the framework for a harrowing, uncommonly unsettling horror film whose cold touch lingers long beyond the closing credits.
Producer: Kevin Scott Frakes, Lars Knudsen, Buddy Patrick

titles: THE SUBTLE ART OF NOT GIVING A #@%!
critics consensus: empty
Producer: Matthew Metcalfe

critics consensus: empty
Producer: Unavailable

critics consensus: A grim, gritty, and gripping super-noir, The Batman ranks among the Dark Knight's bleakest -- and most thrillingly ambitious -- live-action outings.
Producer: Dylan Clark, Matt Reeves

critics consensus: Although She Said struggles to add cinematic flair to its fact-based story, it remains a worthy, well-acted tribute to journalistic integrity.
Producer: Dede Gardner, Jeremy Kleiner

critics consensus: Ana de Armas' luminous performance makes it difficult to look away, but Blonde can be hard to watch as it teeters between commenting on exploitation and contributing to it.
Producer: Dede Gardner, Jeremy Kleiner, Tracey Landon, Brad Pitt, Scott Robertson

critics consensus: Till reframes an historically horrific murder within a mother's grief, brought heartwrenchingly to life by Danielle Deadwyler's tremendous performance.
Producer: Keith Beauchamp, Barbara Broccoli, Whoopi Goldberg, Thomas Levine, Michael Reilly, Frederick Zollo

critics consensus: empty
Producer: Cameron Burns, Emily Gotto, Ben Hanks, Aaron B. Koontz, Pasha Patriki

critics consensus: Violent Night isn't as wildly entertaining as its concept might suggest, but for those seeking harder-edged holiday fare, it may be a ho-ho-whole lot of fun.

critics consensus: Justice is served in Argentina 1985, a crusading courtroom drama that shines a light on historically somber times with refreshing levity.
Producer: Unavailable

critics consensus: Ticket to Paradise may not send viewers all the way to the promised land, but this reunion for a pair of megawatt stars is still an agreeably frothy good time.
Producer: Tim Bevan, Eric Fellner, Sarah Harvey, Deborah Balderstone

critics consensus: A masterful blend of genre elements, The Stranger brings a tautly told mystery to life with simmering tension and a pair of outstanding lead performances.
Producer: Rachel Gardner, Iain Canning, Emile Sherman, Kerry Kohansky-Roberts, Kim Hodgert, Joel Edgerton

critics consensus: empty
Producer: Maciej Kawulski

critics consensus: empty
Producer: Laura M. Young

critics consensus: Pearl finds Ti West squeezing fresh gore out of the world he created with X -- and once again benefiting from a brilliant Mia Goth performance.
Producer: Jacob Jaffke, Harrison Kreiss, Kevin Turen, Ti West

critics consensus: Empathetic and well-acted, The Fallout uses the aftermath of teen trauma to grapple with the experience of grief.
Producer: Shaun Sanghani, Todd Lundbohm, David Brown, Rebecca Miller, Cara Shine, Joannie Burstein, Giulia Prenna

critics consensus: Promisingly cast but misleadingly titled, Uncharted mines its bestselling source material to produce a disappointing echo of superior adventure films.

critics consensus: Sissy weaves timely themes into its rich blend of horror and dark humor, topped off by terrific work from a talented cast led by Aisha Dee.
Producer: Lisa Shaunessy, John De Margheriti, Jason Taylor, Bec Janek

titles: MARCEL THE SHELL WITH SHOES ON
critics consensus: Poignant, profound, and utterly heartwarming, Marcel the Shell with Shoes On is animated entertainment with real heart.
Producer: Dean Fleischer-Camp, Andrew Goldman, Elisabeth Holm, Caroline Kaplan, Terry Leonard, Paul Mezey, Jenny Slate

critics consensus: Emancipation works as an action movie -- albeit one that's uncomfortably at odds with its awkward handling of the real-life events that inspired its stirring story.
Producer: Will Smith, Jon Mone, Joey McFarland, Todd Black

critics consensus: Roald Dahl's Matilda the Musical brings the classic story back to the screen with a delightful Emma Thompson, dazzling dancing, and a suitably irascible take on the source material.

critics consensus: In some ways, Thor: Love and Thunder feels like Ragnarok redux -- but overall, it offers enough fast-paced fun to make this a worthy addition to the MCU.

critics consensus: A tough but rewarding watch, Happening puts a personal face on an impossibly difficult choice and its heart-rending aftermath.
Producer: Alice Girard, Edouard Weil

titles: GOOD LUCK TO YOU, LEO GRANDE
critics consensus: Sexual awakening stories aren't in short supply, but Good Luck to You, Leo Grande proves you can still tell one with a refreshing -- and very funny -- spin.
Producer: Debbie Gray, Adrian Politowski

critics consensus: Featuring genuine scares through every corridor, His House is a terrifying look at the specters of the refugee experience and a stunning feature debut for Remi Weekes.
Producer: Martin Gentles, Ed King

critics consensus: Don't Say A Word is slick and competently made, but the movie is routine and stretches believability with many eye rolling moments.
Producer: Arnon Milchan, Arnold Kopelson, Anne Kopelson

critics consensus: empty
Producer: Mark Andrews, Jessica Bennett, Robert Dean, Stephanie Denton, Bill Kelman, Todd Lundbohm, Andre Relis

critics consensus: Interstellar represents more of the thrilling, thought-provoking, and visually resplendent filmmaking moviegoers have come to expect from writer-director Christopher Nolan, even if its intellectual reach somewhat exceeds its grasp.
Producer: Emma Thomas, Christopher Nolan, Lynda Obst

critics consensus: The rare action thriller that spikes adrenaline without skimping on character development, Prey is a Predator prequel done right.
Producer: John Davis, John Fox, Jhane Myers

critics consensus: The Drop has its finger on the pulse and a game cast trying to keep it alive, but despite its heart being in the right place, this comedy's electrocardiogram is as flat as the Great Plains.
Producer: Lia Buman, Jonako Donley, Mel Eslyn, Shuli Harel, Tim Headington, Joshua Leonard, Sarah Adina Smith

critics consensus: The Gray Man has the star-studded outline of an entertaining action thriller, but it's filled in with lukewarm leftovers from far better films.
Producer: Joe Roth, Jeff Kirschenbaum, Joe Russo, Anthony Russo, Mike Larocca, Chris Castaldi

critics consensus: empty
Producer: Mark Canton, Jennifer Gibgot, Aron Levitz, Brian Pitt, Courtney Solomon

critics consensus: empty
Producer: Rob Cotterill, Josh Goldbloom, Brad Miska, Marc Tetreault, Jason Levangie

critics consensus: Although it raises some uncomfortable ethical quandaries, Wildcat is an affecting testament to the healing power of interspecies bonds.
Director: Melissa Lesh, Trevor Beck Frost, Trevor Frost
Producer: Melissa Lesh, Trevor Beck Frost, Joshua Altman, Alysa Nahmias, Trevor Frost

critics consensus: empty
Producer: Dun He, Bo Huang

critics consensus: Hustle doesn't have any fancy moves, but it doesn't need them -- Adam Sandler's everyman charm makes this easy layup fun to watch.

critics consensus: empty
Producer: Gina Carano, Dallas Sonnier, Amanda Presmyk

critics consensus: Brought to life by a stellar ensemble led by Benedict Cumberbatch, The Power of the Dog reaffirms writer-director Jane Campion as one of her generation's finest filmmakers.
Producer: Jane Campion, Iain Canning, Roger Frappier, Tanya Seghatchian, Emile Sherman

critics consensus: As strange as it is thrillingly ambitious, The Lobster is definitely an acquired taste -- but for viewers with the fortitude to crack through Yorgos Lanthimos' offbeat sensibilities, it should prove a savory cinematic treat.
Producer: Ed Guiney, Lee Magiday, Ceci Dempsey, Yorgos Lanthimos

critics consensus: House of Darkness finds writer-director Neil LaBute just as acerbic as ever, although he's made more compelling statements on sexual mores.

critics consensus: Although it may strike some as too artsy for its own good, You Won't Be Alone puts a thoughtfully fresh spin on familiar horror tropes.

critics consensus: Sing Street is a feel-good musical with huge heart and irresistible optimism, and its charmimg cast and hummable tunes help to elevate its familiar plotting.
Producer: Anthony Bregman, Martina Niland, John Carney

critics consensus: The Swimmers can be heavy-handed and it's arguably too long, but it handles a worthy topic with generally uplifting results.
Producer: Tim Bevan, Eric Fellner, Tim Cole, Ali Jaafar

critics consensus: Arguably the best screen version of this oft-adapted tale, Lady Chatterley's Lover sets itself apart with solid acting and a refreshingly frank treatment of the story's mature themes.
Producer: Graham Broadbent, Peter Czernin, Elizabeth Gabler, Laurence Mark

critics consensus: The Good Nurse is hobbled by stilted dialogue and unrealistic story elements, but those issues are offset by strong work from a pair of talented leads.
Producer: Scott Franklin, Darren Aronofsky, Michael A. Jackman

critics consensus: There's no dearth of possession stories within the genre, and potboiler Prey for the Devil may leave completists needing a truly horrific -- or at least fun -- exorcist palate cleanser.
Producer: Paul Brooks, Todd R. Jones, Earl Richey Jones, Jessica Malanaphy

critics consensus: Descendant serves as a fantastically compelling example of how history can be reclaimed -- and a stirring tribute to a resilient community.
Producer: Margaret Brown, Essie Chambers, Kyle Martin

critics consensus: Academy Award® nominee Cynthia Erivo is the Blue Fairy
Producer: Unavailable

critics consensus: Led by Anna Diop's strong central performance, the smartly disquieting Nanny is a promising debut for writer-director Nikyatu Jusu.
Producer: Nikkia Moulterie, Daniela Taplin Lundberg

critics consensus: A sweet swan song for director Roger Michell, The Duke offers a well-acted and engaging dramatization of an entertainingly improbable true story.
Producer: Nicky Bentham

critics consensus: Prisoners has an emotional complexity and a sense of dread that makes for absorbing (and disturbing) viewing.
Producer: Broderick Johnson, Kira Davis, Andrew A. Kosove, Adam Kolbrenner

critics consensus: Bros marks a step forward in rom-com representation -- and just as importantly, it's a whole bunch of fun to watch.
Producer: Judd Apatow, Nicholas Stoller, Joshua Church

critics consensus: At top speed and with sirens wailing, Ambulance comes riding to the rescue for audiences facing an emergency shortage of Michael Bay action thrills.
Producer: Michael Bay, Bradley J. Fischer, James Vanderbilt, William Sherak, Ian Bryce

critics consensus: Searching's timely premise and original execution are further bolstered by well-rounded characters brought to life by a talented cast.
Distributor: Screen Gems, Sony Pictures Entertainment, Stage 6
Producer: Timur Bekmambetov, Sev Ohanian, Adam Sidman, Natalie Qasabian

critics consensus: Exciting, entertaining, and emotionally impactful, Avengers: Endgame does whatever it takes to deliver a satisfying finale to Marvel's epic Infinity Saga.
Producer: Kevin Feige

critics consensus: The Outfit isn't flashy, but a solid story and Mark Rylance's tightly tailored performance make this a comfortable fit for fans of old-school thrillers.
Producer: Ben Browning, Amy Jackson, Scoop Wasserstein

critics consensus: Closer's talented cast and Mike Nichols' typically assured direction help smooth a bumpy journey from stage to screen.
Producer: Robert Fox, Scott Rudin, John Calley, Cary Brokaw

critics consensus: A nerve-wracking continuation of its predecessor, A Quiet Place Part II expands the terrifying world of the franchise without losing track of its heart.
Producer: Michael Bay, Andrew Form, Brad Fuller, John Krasinski

critics consensus: Delightfully dark and impressively ambitious, A Wounded Fawn offers a grimly distinctive treat for slasher fans.
Producer: Travis Stevens, Joe Barbagallo, Laurence Gendron

critics consensus: A visually dazzling puzzle for film lovers to unlock, Tenet serves up all the cerebral spectacle audiences expect from a Christopher Nolan production.
Producer: Emma Thomas, Christopher Nolan

critics consensus: Dune occasionally struggles with its unwieldy source material, but those issues are largely overshadowed by the scope and ambition of this visually thrilling adaptation.
Producer: Denis Villeneuve, Mary Parent, Cale Boyter, Joseph Caracciolo Jr.

titles: WE'RE ALL GOING TO THE WORLD'S FAIR
critics consensus: Narratively challenging and visually haunting, We're All Going to the World's Fair adds a uniquely ambitious and unsettling entry to the crowded coming-of-age genre.
Producer: Sarah Winshall, Carlos Zozaya, Abby Harri

critics consensus: A painfully timely horror-fueled thriller, Soft & Quiet forces the viewer to confront the ugly underbelly of modern American race relations.
Producer: Joshua Beirne-Golden, Josh Peters, Saba Zerehi,

critics consensus: Troll doesn't rewrite the monster movie rulebooks -- but with mythology this rich and action this exciting, it doesn't have to.
Producer: Espen Horn, Kristian Strand Sinkerud, Jasmin Torbati

critics consensus: It may not win writer-director Guy Ritchie many new converts, but for those already attuned to the filmmaker's brash wavelength, The Gentlemen stands tall.
Producer: Guy Ritchie, Ivan Atkinson, Bill Block

titles: BARDO, FALSE CHRONICLE OF A HANDFUL OF TRUTHS
critics consensus: As deeply personal as it is demanding, Bardo, False Chronicle of a Handful of Truths unsteadily walks the line between brilliance and sheer self-indulgence.
Producer: Alejandro González Iñárritu, Stacy Perskie

titles: DOCTOR STRANGE IN THE MULTIVERSE OF MADNESS
critics consensus: Doctor Strange in the Multiverse of Madness labors under the weight of the sprawling MCU, but Sam Raimi's distinctive direction casts an entertaining spell.
Producer: Kevin Feige

critics consensus: empty
Producer: Neil Chisholm, Shane Stanley, CJ Walley

titles: ONCE UPON A TIME... IN HOLLYWOOD
critics consensus: Thrillingly unrestrained yet solidly crafted, Once Upon a Time in Hollywood tempers Tarantino's provocative impulses with the clarity of a mature filmmaker's vision.
Producer: David Heyman, Shannon McIntosh, Quentin Tarantino

critics consensus: empty
Producer: Allison Maier, Lane Skye, Ruckus Skye, Martin Kelley, Gabriel Olson, Danielle Deadwyler

critics consensus: Stylish, thrilling, and giddily kinetic, John Wick serves as a satisfying return to action for Keanu Reeves -- and what looks like it could be the first of a franchise.
Producer: Basil Iwanyk, David Leitch, Eva Longoria

critics consensus: A social satire with razor-sharp teeth, Speak No Evil offers a darkly delicious treat for fans of misanthropic thrillers.
Producer: Jacob Jarek

critics consensus: Smart, original, and above all terrifying, It Follows is the rare modern horror film that works on multiple levels -- and leaves a lingering sting.
Producer: Rebecca Green, Laura D. Smith, David Robert Mitchell, David Kaplan, Erik Rommesmo

critics consensus: Whether as a story of one couple's quixotic quest or simply a stunning collection of nature footage, Fire of Love burns bright.
Producer: Shane Boris, Ina Fichman, Sara Dosa

critics consensus: Somber, stately, and beautifully mounted, Sam Mendes' Road to Perdition is a well-crafted mob movie that explores the ties between fathers and sons.
Producer: Sam Mendes, Richard D. Zanuck, Dean Zanuck

critics consensus: Intense, inspiring, and well-acted, Whiplash is a brilliant sophomore effort from director Damien Chazelle and a riveting vehicle for stars J.K. Simmons and Miles Teller.
Producer: Helen Estabrook, Jason Blum, Michel Litvak, David Lancaster

critics consensus: Fast-paced, funny, and full of colorful visual appeal, The Bad Guys is good news for audiences seeking options the whole family can enjoy.
Producer: Rebecca Huntley, Damon Ross

critics consensus: As Kenny Rogers told us, you've got to know when to fold 'em -- a warning Russell Crowe should have heeded when he got the script for Poker Face.
Producer: Addam Bramich, Jason Clark, Mark B. David, Gary Hamilton, Ryan Hamilton, Keith Rodger, , Matt Williams, Ying Ye

critics consensus: Four Good Days struggles to bring authenticity to its tragic source material and strands its talent in a bland melodrama.
Producer: Jacob Avnet, Jon Avnet, Rodrigo Garcia, Marina Grasic, Jai Khanna

critics consensus: Hell or High Water offers a solidly crafted, well-acted Western heist thriller that eschews mindless gunplay in favor of confident pacing and full-bodied characters.
Producer: Sidney Kimmel, Peter Berg, Carla Hacken, Julie Yorn

critics consensus: A Man Called Ove's winsome sincerity -- and Rolf Lassgård's affectingly flinty performance in the title role -- keep it from succumbing to excess sentimentality.

critics consensus: Amy Adams is as appealing as ever, but her charms aren't enough to keep Leap Year from succumbing to an overabundance of clichés and an unfunny script.

critics consensus: Funny, scary, and thought-provoking, Get Out seamlessly weaves its trenchant social critiques into a brilliantly effective and entertaining horror/comedy thrill ride.

critics consensus: Aided by stellar performances from Jessie Buckley and Jesse Plemons, I'm Thinking of Ending Things finds writer-director Charlie Kaufman grappling with the human condition as only he can.
Producer: Stefanie Azpiazu, Anthony Bregman, Charlie Kaufman, Robert Salerno

critics consensus: An ambitious superhero epic that soars as often as it strains, Eternals takes the MCU in intriguing -- and occasionally confounding -- new directions.
Producer: Kevin Feige, Nate Moore

critics consensus: empty
Producer: Justin Folk, Dallas Sonnier, Charlotte Roland

critics consensus: If its narrative and thematic reach sometimes exceeds its grasp, magnetic performances from a stellar cast help Men make the most of its horror provocations.
Producer: Andrew Macdonald, Allon Reich, Scott Rudin, Eli Bush

critics consensus: Thanks to a script that emphasizes its heroes' humanity and a wealth of superpowered set pieces, The Avengers lives up to its hype and raises the bar for Marvel at the movies.
Producer: Kevin Feige

critics consensus: Brilliantly brought to life by tenderly empathetic performances from Jay Duplass and Edie Falco, Outside In tells a sobering -- yet thoroughly absorbing -- story.
Producer: Mel Eslyn, Lacey Leavitt

critics consensus: The Lost City doesn't sparkle quite as brightly as some classic treasure-hunting capers, but its stars' screwball chemistry make this movie well worth romancing.

critics consensus: Led by outstanding work from Emily Blunt and Benicio del Toro, Sicario is a taut, tightly wound thriller with much more on its mind than attention-getting set pieces.
Producer: Basil Iwanyk, Edward L. McDonnell, Molly Smith, Thad Luckinbill, Trent Luckinbill

critics consensus: Luckiest Girl Alive means well and Mila Kunis does strong work in the central role, but those positive points are overshadowed by a treatment that risks trivializing its themes.
Producer: Bruna Papandrea, Jeanne Snow, Erik Feig,

critics consensus: Heartwarming, humorous, beautifully animated, and culturally expansive, Turning Red extends Pixar's long list of family-friendly triumphs.
Producer: Lindsey Collins

critics consensus: More visually impressive than narratively engaging, Vesper rewards patient viewers with immersive world-building and intelligent ideas.
Producer: Asta Liukaityte, Daiva Varnaite-Jovaisienne, Kristina Buozyte, Alexis Perrin

critics consensus: Under the Shadow deftly blends seemingly disparate genres to deliver an effective chiller with timely themes and thought-provoking social subtext.
Producer: Emily Leo, Oliver Roskill, Lucan Toh

critics consensus: Something in the Dirt reaffirms Justin Benson and Aaron Moorhead as sci-fi storytellers with a distinctive -- and darkly alluring -- vision.
Producer: David Lawson Jr., Aaron Moorhead, Justin Benson

critics consensus: If it falls short of the deadly satire of Bret Easton Ellis's novel, American Psycho still finds its own blend of horror and humor, thanks in part to a fittingly creepy performance by Christian Bale.
Producer: Christian Halsey Solomon, Chris Hanley, Edward R. Pressman

critics consensus: An urgent, brilliantly layered look at timely social themes, Parasite finds writer-director Bong Joon Ho in near-total command of his craft.
Producer: Kwak Sin-ae, Moon Yanggwon

critics consensus: Paddington 2 honors its star's rich legacy with a sweet-natured sequel whose adorable visuals are matched by a story perfectly balanced between heartwarming family fare and purely enjoyable all-ages adventure.
Producer: David Heyman

critics consensus: Causeway takes a powerfully subdued look at the lingering effects of trauma, led by gripping performances from Jennifer Lawrence and Brian Tyree Henry.
Producer: Jennifer Lawrence, Justine Polsky

critics consensus: Although it struggles to maintain its thrilling early momentum, Last Night in Soho shows flashes of Edgar Wright at his most stylish and ambitious.
Producer: Nira Park, Tim Bevan, Eric Fellner, Laura Richardson, Edgar Wright
